themes.label: Decrees
themes.rationale: The text is a formal resolution passed by the Athenian assembly, explicitly referred to as a 'psephisma' (decree).
themes.quote: ἀναγράψαι δὲ τόδε τὸ ψήφισμα εἰς στήλην λιθίνην

themes.label: Honorific Inscriptions
themes.rationale: The inscription records the Athenian people bestowing honors and gratitude upon a benefactor for his goodwill.
themes.quote: ὁ δῆμος Ἀθηναίων ἀποδίδωσιν χάριτας μεγάλας τοῖς εὐεργετοῦσιν

themes.label: Laws and Regulations
themes.rationale: The text involves the 'nomothetai' (lawgivers) and the process of 'prosnomethetesai' (additional legislation) regarding the allocation of funds.
themes.quote: ἐν δὲ τοῖς νομοθέταις τοὺς προέδρους οἳ ἂν προεδρεύωσιν καὶ τὸν ἐπιστάτην προσνομοθετῆσαι

themes.label: Accounts and Financial Records
themes.rationale: The decree specifies financial disbursements, including thirty drachmas for the stele and a daily drachma for Peisitheides' maintenance.
themes.quote: δότω ταμίας τοῦ δήμου τριάκοντα δραχμάς ... διδόναι Πεισιθείδει δραχμὴν τῆς ἡμέρας

themes.label: Stele
themes.rationale: The text explicitly commands that the decree be inscribed on a stone stele.
themes.quote: ἀναγράψαι δὲ τόδε τὸ ψήφισμα εἰς στήλην λιθίνην

themes.label: Other Stone
themes.rationale: The inscription describes the material as 'lithine' (stone).

themes.label: Fragmentary
themes.rationale: The text contains numerous lacunae and reconstructed sections, indicating it is not fully preserved.

persons.name: Peisitheides
persons.role: Benefactor and recipient of Athenian citizenship and maintenance

places.name: Akropolis
places.type: Sanctuary and location of the stele

places.name: Delos
places.type: Island or city of origin for Peisitheides

rationale: This inscription is an Athenian decree from 334 BC honoring Peisitheides of Delos. It grants him Athenian citizenship (naturalization) and provides a daily maintenance allowance (trophe) of one drachma. The text outlines the administrative procedures for recording the decree on the Akropolis, the financial responsibilities of the treasurer (tamias), and the involvement of the lawgivers (nomothetai) to ensure the funding is properly allocated. It also includes a protection clause declaring anyone who kills Peisitheides an enemy of the Athenian people.
